page.title: 09CHURCH STREET
page.content: Without doubt, Church Street is the oldest street in Warrington. At its eastern end stands Warrington Parish Church, dedicated to St.Elphin. The church stands on the site of a Saxon church and has a spire 281 feet high - a landmark for miles around. Originally the centre of Warrington, the church is now two-thirds of a mile from the town-centre, but is still the centre for civic occasions. A market was once held in the street, a charter for which was granted in 1277. Church Street contains two tudor cottages, next to which is the site of an hostelry where Oliver Cromwell stayed in 1648. There is also the National School, Warrington's first elementary school, founded by public subscription in 1833. The area has recently been designated a conservation area.
